Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
In 2015, as part of a series of cybersecurity initiatives made public by the U.K. Prime Minister and the U.S. President, the two nations announced that MIT's Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (CSAIL) and the University of Cambridge, would organize a special collaborative competition in cybersecurity dubbed Cambridge2Cambridge. The event took place in 2016 at MIT and the two universities agreed to a follow-on event, to be held in the summer of 2017. Cambridge University will host this event at their campus in the U.K. and the event will include several schools from the United States. Thirty-one U.S. students have been selected based on their performance in a preliminary contest including students from MIT, Carnegie-Mellon University, Columbia University, United States Air Force Academy, Worcester Polytechnic Institute, University of Tampa and University of Puerto Rico. All of the U.K. Centers of Cyber Excellence (sponsored by the Government Communications Headquarters, GCHQ) will participate and represent the U.K.

This project promotes international cooperation in cybersecurity, furthering relationships between countries and among students. Several private companies with advanced cybersecurity capabilities, including Boeing, BP, Raytheon, BAE Systems, State Farm Insurance and Akamai, will provide mentors for student participants. They will encourage students to consider careers in a field that is intellectually challenging and of critical importance to U.S. and international security. This award is co-funded by the Global Venture Fund from the NSF's Office of International Science and Engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In 2015 the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (in Cambridge, Massachusetts) and the University of Cambridge (in Cambridge, UK), jointly launched “Cambridge 2 Cambridge”, a cybersecurity challenge for students to learn about and demonstrate competence in cyber-security techniques.. Announced in January 2015 by US President Barack Obama and UK Prime Minister David Cameron in the context of greater cybersecurity collaboration between the two countries, the competition gave the students the opportunity to explore creative ways to combat global cyber attacks and acquire and hone crucial skills.
Held in March 2016, the inaugural event brought together top students from both universities at MIT’s Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (CSAIL) in Cambridge, MA to compete.  The second annual Cambridge 2 Cambridge competition was held at the historic Trinity College on the University of Cambridge campus in the UK.  This second competition included students from across the U.S. and U.K. with MIT and Cambridge University continuing to take the lead in organizing the event. 
Students from the U.S. were selected in an online qualifying round that included both tutorial sessions and challenge problems; The U.K. conducted an equivalent but separate qualifying round.Selected participants from the qualifying round competed in the live three-day showdown with over 100 competitors from the US and UK. The event took place the University of Cambridge July 24-26, 2017. Students competed in a graduated set of exercises in binary exploitation, web security, reverse engineering, cryptography and forensics in a scored CTF competition, along with several open interactive activities.
The event satisfied both goals of enhancing students' skills and building relationships between U.S. and U.K. cyber security students.
All told there were:111 participants22 teams of 5 students each. 80 UK studentsand 31 US students participated.
Videos, pictures and summaries of the event are available at https://cambridge2cambridge.csail.mit.eduEach of the 22 teams consisted of students from both the U.K. and U.S. and no team contained more than 1 member from the same home institution. The following is a list of the participating U.S. universities:
1. Massachusetts Institute of Technology (Host University) 2. California State Polytechnic University, Pomona3. Carnegie Mellon University4. Columbia University5. Dakota State University6. Rochester Institute of Technology (RIT) 7. Stanford University8. United States Air Force Academy9. University of Arizona10. University of California, Berkeley11. University of Maryland, Baltimore County12. Worcester Polytechnic Institute

The students who participated were offered a unique opportunity to learn about real-world cyber security issues. Throughout the process, they were offered mentorship from highly experienced personnel both at the organizing universities and at cyber security companies. In addition, the team-building experience was invaluable in developing a network of future collaborators from the two countries.
The students who participated were offered a unique opportunity to learn about real-world cyber security issues. Throughout the process, they were offered mentorship from highly experienced personnel both at the organizing universities and at cyber security companies. In addition, the team-building experience was invaluable in developing a network of future collaborators from the two countries.
A detailed report of the event has been posted on the Cambridge2Cambridge website: https://cambridge2cambridge.csail.mit.edu. This includes several videos also posted at UTube.
